Environment Variable Method

If event information is passed through environment variables, the event trigger queries the environment for values it needs. For example, a batch file might query %EVENTARCHIVE%, a UNIX shell script might query $EVENTARCHIVE, a build script would query $(EVENTARCHIVE), and a C program would perform a getenv("EVENTARCHIVE") function call.

An example of a Windows batch file named POSTPUT.BAT:

H:\PUBLIC\SEND "Just checked in %EVENTWORKFILE%, revision %EVENTREVISION% to group %EVENTGROUP%"

The event trigger

POSTPUT C:\BIN\POSTPUT.BAT

sends a message to a work group after Version Manager successfully checks in a workfile.

An example of a UNIX shell file named postput:

/usr/pvcstools/send "Just checked in $EVENTWORKFILE, revision $EVENTREVISION to group $EVENTGROUP"

The event trigger

POSTPUT /usr/bin/postput

sends a message to a work group after Version Manager successfully checks in a workfile.
